abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews exhibition of works by 13 artists entitled Human/Nature at Caren Golden gallery (S)

block.p: Caren Golden 526 West 26th Street Chelsea Through next Friday

The old nature-culture duality gets a diversified workout in this entertaining show. What comes through overall is a feeling not of closeness to nature but of distance, as if the 13 artists included were speculating about the rumor of some strange, little-known dimension of reality.

In a neatly fabricated machine by John Kalymnios, illuminated photo-transparencies of rippled water slide back and forth, creating the hypnotic illusion of slow, oceanic rolling; the moving image is in turn projected by video onto an adjacent wall, creating a small blurry image that is like a fragment from a barely remembered dream.
Caren Golden 526 West 26th Street Chelsea Through next Friday

The old nature-culture duality gets a diversified workout in this entertaining show. What comes through overall is a feeling not of closeness to nature but of distance, as if the 13 artists included were speculating about the rumor of some strange, little-known dimension of reality.

In a neatly fabricated machine by John Kalymnios, illuminated photo-transparencies of rippled water slide back and forth, creating the hypnotic illusion of slow, oceanic rolling; the moving image is in turn projected by video onto an adjacent wall, creating a small blurry image that is like a fragment from a barely remembered dream.

Not naturalism, indeed, but surrealism: Marguerite Kahrl's funny ''Conversation With a Luddite'' ensconces a little reproduction of the Unabomber's cabin in a papier-mache tree; from it issues the recorded discourse of someone with complicated anti-modernist theories.
Roxy Paine creates magically realistic cow pies from which psychedelic mushrooms sprout.

Nina Katchadorian shows photographs of mushrooms to which she has added colorful rubber patches. And Austin Thomas photographs or paints pictures of ordinary-looking stones and adds odd, typewritten diaristic stories about them.
One senses some autobiographical meaning in an oblique but haunting three-part installation by Robert Beck.

It includes a video of a taxidermist working on a deer hide to the sound of an Al Green song; a goofy little deer sculpture made from a toilet paper roll; and a shelf with the photograph of a grizzled farmer holding a yearbook portrait of a young man -- his son, maybe, who, one cannot help guessing, must have died in a hunting accident.
